IFITM3 expression delays reovirus outer capsid cleavage. cells were washed 2 times with PBS, pelleted at 3000 g, and resuspended in radioimmunoprecipitation buffer. cell entry represents a very attractive target, as all viruses require some mechanism to penetrate into a host cell either at the cell surface, via endosomes, or via other cell transport events. many viruses require the use of endosomal compartments for proteolytic cleavage or pH-dependent conformational changes necessary for membrane fusion or penetration. the precise mechanism of action for IFITM3 is not fully understood. IFN treatment or IFITM3 expression expands late endosomal and autolysosomal compartments (14, 49), indicative of changes in the activity of these structures. changes could alter the rate of acidification of endosomes before delivery of the components to lysosomes, influence cathepsin activity. a previous study indicated that particles that do not efficiently penetrate endosomes localize to lysosomes (23). we cannot exclude the possibility that IFITM3 also alters the properties of endosomal membranes to prevent membrane penetration. alterations in this region of the protein also affect sensitivity to IFITM3. many nonenveloped viruses require access to endosomal compartments for membrane penetration. however, the precise endosomal dynamics required for these viruses to penetrate membranes differ.
